Sifttter Redux: Automate IFTTT to Day One

Feb 13, 2014
1 minute read

A while back, I mentioned Sifttter, a method for getting IFTTT data into a Day One Journal. It’s an elegant solution, but one aspect of it bothered me from the start: I couldn’t schedule Sifttter to run without leaving my MacBook on at night. I didn’t like that.

I wanted a solution that ran on its own. After configuring it, my ideal script would run every night at 11:55pm, grab the necessary data from IFTTT, and put it in my Day One journal, all without me having to manually kick off a process.

Today, I’m proud to introduce that solution: Sifttter Redux. It uses the same base as Sifttter, but adds key functionality on top of it:

  • Interactive logging of today’s events or events in the past
  • “Catch Up” mode for logging several days’ events at once
  • Packaged as a command line app, complete with documentation and help
  • Easy installation on cron for automated running

TL;DR

Sifttter Redux is an app that automatically syncs various services’ data (Foursquare, Last.FM, etc.) to a Day One journal.

Setting Up Sifttter Redux

Set up IFTTT Recipes

Craig’s original set-up guide can be followed for Sifttter Redux, as well.

Download and Configure Sifttter Redux

Full configuration instructions can be found on the project’s GitHub page.

Other Thoughts

This script has come a long way, but there are several features I’d like to add going forward. If there are bugs or features that you’d like to report, please use the project’s Issues page.

I’d like to extend a big thank-you to Craig Eley (and by extension, Brett Terpstra) for their effort in advancing this idea. I see Sifttter Redux as a logical contribution to the work these two have already done and am grateful to have piggybacked on their ideas.

I’ve installed and tested this on my Raspberry Pi without issue. That said, this script should run on any *NIX system. Let me know in the comments if you have particular questions and I will help as best I can.
